overview_of_class:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / Nature and control of major air pollution sources. Physical and chemical properties and effects of major air pollutants. Analytical measurements and monitoring of air pollutants; engineering and legislative control.

COURSE OBJECTIVES / The objective of the course is to introduce students to issues of air quality and air quality management: pollutants, health effects, modeling of air quality, control strategies and control of emissions.

TOPICS TO BE COVERED:
*** Introduction and review of air quality legislation;
*** Common measures for expressing air quality concentrations, and
calculation procedures including correction for temperature and pressure;
*** Use of lognormal distribution in describing size distributions of particles;
*** Sources and health effects of pollutants regulated under NAAQS;
*** Forces affecting winds, and calculation of speeds for the common equilibrium winds;
*** Air quality modeling;
*** Emission control processes: description and analysis of performance; and
*** Regulatory issues affecting emissions control and regional air quality.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students successfully completing the course will be able to:

1. Identify pollutants regulated under the Ambient Air Quality Standards and one or more standards for each;
2. Express concentrations in ppmv and g/m3 at various temperatures and pressures;
3. Determine the geometric mean and standard deviation of particle size distribution data, and calculate the count median and mass median diameters;
4. Model air quality using box, plume and puff models;
5. Identify regulatory measures and strategies affecting air quality and emission control;
6. Analyze the performance of common emission control systems;
7. Identify and describe the basic concepts of land pollution engineering;
8. Describe the basic factors and equations governing flow and pollution transport in groundwater;
9. Apply basic land pollution concepts to estimate remediation standards.
